references.A63NEI01NAUS: Neill, W.T. 1963. HEMIDACTYLIUM SCUTATUM. CATALOGUE OF AMERICAN AMPHIBIANS AND REPTILES. SSAR NO.2:1-2.
references.B81VOG01NAUS: Vogt, R. G. 1981. Natural history of amphibians and reptiles of Wisconsin. Milwaukee Public Museum. 205 pp.
references.B98PET01NCGP: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
references.U12NCW01USGP: North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission. 2012. Conservation Recommendations for Priority Terrestrial Wildlife Species and Habitats in North Carolina. 96 pages.
references.A82KIL01NAUS: Kilpatrick, C.W. 1982. HEMIDACTYLIUM SCUTATUM (FOUR-TOED SALAMANDER). HERPETOL. REV. 13(1):23-24.
references.B80MAR01NAUS: Martof, B. S., W. M. Palmer, J. R. Bailey, and J. R. Harrison, III. 1980. Amphibians and reptiles of the Carolinas and Virginia. University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 264 pp.
references.A34BLA01NAUS: Blanchard, F.N. 1934. Late autumn collections and hibernating situations of the salamandar Hemidactylium scutatum (Schlegel) in southern Michigan. Copeia. 1933:216.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.
references.A23BLA01NAUS: Blanchard, F.N. 1923. The life history of the four-toed salamander. Amer. Nat., 57:262-268.
references.B93KLE01NAUS: Klemens, M. W. 1993. Amphibians and reptiles of Connecticut and adjacent regions. State Geological and Natural History Survey of Connecticut, Bulletin 112. xii + 318 pp.
references.B77JOH01NAUS: Johnson, T. R. 1977. The amphibians of Missouri. Univ. Kansas Mus. Nat. Hist., Pub. Ed. Ser. 6. ix + 134 pp.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.A34BLA03NAUS: Blanchard, F.N. 1934. The spring migration of the four-toed salamander Hemidactylium scutatum. Copeia. 1934:50.
references.B71BAR01NAUS: Barbour, R. W. 1971. Amphibians and reptiles of Kentucky. Univ. Press of Kentucky, Lexington. x + 334 pp.
references.A88WOO03NAUS: Woodley, S. J., and M. Rosen. 1988. First record of the four-toed salamander, HEMIDACTYLIUM SCUTATUM, in New Brunswick. Canadian Field-Nat. 102:712.
references.B72MIN01NAUS: Minton, S. A., Jr. 1972. Amphibians and reptiles of Indiana. Indiana Academy Science Monographs 3. v + 346 pp.
references.A34BLA02NAUS: Blanchard, F.N. 1934. The relation of the female four-toed salamander to her nest. Copeia. 1934 (3):137-138.
references.A90SHA02NAUS: Sharbel, T. F. 1990. A range extension for the four-toed salamander, HEMIDACTYLIUM SCUTATUM, in southern Quebec. Canadian Field-Naturalist 105:285-286.
references.A82BRE01NAUS: Breitenbach, G.L. 1982. The frequency of communal nesting and solitary brooding in the salamander, HEMIDACTYLUM SCUTATUM. J. Herpetology. 16 (4):341-346.

habitat_description: Four-toed salamanders may be observed in scattered locations throughout much of their range in swamps, bogs, moist terrestrial seeps and springs, floodplains, sloughs or standing water, vernal ponds, and marshy areas within hardwood or mixed forest.  Although terrestrial or fossorial as adults, four-toed salamanders are aquatic as larvae, and require a breeding habitat near water; preferably in fishless habitats with sphagnum or other mosses present.  They breed in the fall and lay eggs in the winter or early spring.  Clutch size is variously reported as a dozen or so up to 80.  The eggs are laid in moss or other protected sites immediately above or next to a pool, into which the larvae drop or wriggle after hatching.  The female remains with her eggs until hatching (about 2 months) and communal nesting occurs.  The aquatic larvae metamorphose in about 1.5-2 months and attain sexual maturity about 18 months later.  Thought to be declining, especially due to habitat loss (Petranka 1998).  S. Smith 18Feb05
